results.title: Otto Messmer and Felix the Cat
results.brief_description: Presents a tribute to Otto Messmer and his famous cartoon character, Felix the Cat. Features the cartoonist, who describes the evolution of Felix’s personality, and includes excerpts from five vintage shorts starring Felix the Cat. Music by Ross Care. Camera by Richard W. Adams. Written by John Canemaker.

results.title: Ottawa: reflection of a nation
results.brief_description: Canada’s capital city is viewed here in its spring-time splendour. A colorful parade of the Guards on Parliament Hill, the escort of an ambassador in coach-and-four, and away from the pageantry the wildlife refuge of Gatineau Park are featured.

results.title: Ottawa: Canada's capital
results.brief_description: A picture of Ottawa photographed in tulip time. Explores the many beauty spots in and around the city and shows how Ottawa has made use of its many natural endowments to develop a unique capital city.

results.title: Ottawa, today and tomorrow
results.brief_description: Planning experts redesigning Ottawa consider its potentialities as a national capital. Animation shows how it began as a lumbering town at the junction of three rivers. Points out some of its undesirable features and shows the master plan embodying good town-planning principles and highlighting its scenic waterways, drives, and Houses of Parliament.

results.title: Otherwise known as Sheila the great
results.brief_description: Ten year old Sheila Tubman faces some of her worst fears, including swimming, dogs and the dark, when her family spends the summer in the countryside of Tarrytown. In Tarrytown, Sheila meets Mouse Ellis, Junior Yo Yo Champion, dog lover and terrific swimmer. Sheila pretends to Mouse that she is not afraid of anything…but Mouse is not fooled. Based on the story by best-selling children’s writer, Judy Blume.

results.title: Others
results.creator_credit: Gene Feldman and Wombat Productions, Inc.
results.brief_description: A young boy treated unfairly by his teacher, seeks refuge in solitude and other relationships. Ultimately he is faced with accepting the teacher’s tentative approaches or withdrawing into himself.

results.title: Other planets: no place like Earth (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Bert Shapiro, Lothar Wolff, National Educational Television and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life Around Us”.
This film summarises the knowledge that scientists have gathered about the planets, covering such subjects as the seasonal changes on Mars, the atmosphere of Venus, the motion of Jupiter, the rings of Saturn, the discoveries of Neptune and Pluto. Through computer animation, viewers are taken on a “grand tour” of the outer planets (Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune) simulating a trip actually planned for an unmanned space ship in the late 1970s.

results.title: Other people's wars
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Last dream: a special report by John Pilger”.
The final episode of a three part series which explores aspects of Australia’s history. This part shows how Australians fight mostly against people with whom they have no quarrel and who offer them no threat of invasion. From the Boxer Rebellion in China to the Boer War in Africa, to the disaster in Vietnam, Australians have paid a unique blood sacrifice to appease a great protector.

results.title: Other people's property
results.brief_description: Focuses attention on the problem of vandalism and the need for respect for other people’s property. The film tells the story of three boys who caused damage to a schoolroom because they failed to think about the possible consequences of their actions. The roles of each of the three boys involved in the incident are discussed and the point made that the prank would not have happened if each boy had acted on his own conscience.

results.title: Other People's Money
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
Part Three of a ten part documentary “Filmstruck”, which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience. In this episode, John Baxter, well known Australian film historian and cinema critic, explains that without the Hollywood studios’ money independent producers had to find backers. This program includes interviews with top Australian producers.
